Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2011 06:20AM wonderfullymade wrote: Gentle ((HUGS)) and prayers for answers and healing thoughts to you! You know your body and it is telling you that something is wrong. Try to work through the process and not burrow any worries. Your doctor is getting you in quickly to see qualified examiners. He is not a breast specialist. There are many types of breast infections and other breast conditions that can cause your symptoms that are not cancer, as flash stated. I am very happy to know that you are getting check out soon so that you can be treated and know what you are dealing with. It is still likely to be a b9 breast condition, so take a deep breathe and work throught the process! More ((HUGS)) to you!!!
Posts.Title: Could I have IBC? So scared.......can anyone help, please? maedmarion Lisa1962

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 06:24PM wonderfullymade wrote: maedmarion, Thanks so much for your kind words. I will be celebrating the first anniversary of the non for profit that I co founded for mommies with kiddos who are affected by autism Friday night and I pray to have much more to celebrate as well. Regardless of the outcome I trust that God will give me abundant strength to get through this season of worry. When my mom, dad, and gma passed away this summer within just 12 sort weeks of oneanother, I felt tired and emotionally spent at times, yet He continued to sustain me through every moment of trial and wiped every tear. I gained an amazing percpective on life and cherish each and every moment now. It is amazing how much we can learn through suffering if we chose to allow it. I feel I am a better person having suffered through cancer with them all. If I am forced to battle the beast, I know He will give me armor, and you all will suit up with me! I will be praying for you tomorrow and will check in! xoxoxox
Posts.Title: Could I have IBC? So scared.......can anyone help, please? maedmarion Lisa1962

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 07:21AM wonderfullymade wrote: maedmarion, Sweet thoughts and gentle hugs for you as you anxiously await your appointment. The waiting is very hard for me as well. I am on pins and needles and black and blue after my biopsy yesterday. They vacuumed a ton of tissue and apparently hit some capillaries, ouch! The pain has been a distraction though and made me slow down. With two small boys with autism, I rarely ever take time for me or slow down. I will know more of God's plan for me Friday afternoon. Just gonna take it all in stride and try to learn from this experience, perhaps I will be able to comfort another someday. Please be reassured that you are in my prayers. May God surround you with grace and peace through this....MUWAH!!!

Posts.Title: Could I have IBC? So scared.......can anyone help, please? maedmarion Lisa1962

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2014 08:03AM wonderfullymade wrote: Although each person deals with stress in a unique way, I can share after many biopsies and waiting agony, Â I have learned to stay busy to keep my mind from focusing on possible cancer dx. Easier said then done. But you know...most results are b9. In addition it is what it is and a week will not change the outcome. Try to take each step as it comes. These are things I tell myself and have learned to actually do, but it took a few times to get there. I have imaging every 6mos and they stick a needle in anything that looks even remotely suspected due to my high risk so I have had 8 now and I am 41. Know that many of us are supporting you and thinking of you. It is ok to worry. We all fear the unknown...that's natural. Try to surround yourself with comforting people..that helps too. Hugs!

Posts.Title: ductal excision neochiq PegPinGa

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2011 04:07AM wonderfullymade wrote: Debbie, I can tell you that I think having a risk assesment done is a great tool for gathering information so that can make the right decision for you. I am 36 and am waiting for my biopsy results that will be in on Wed. Because of my intense family history of bc in both my mom and gma, along with my dad's pancreatic cancer and my younger brother's stuggle with colon cancer, my risk of developing bc or ovarian cancer is over 30% even without the gene. I will also know if I am brca + wed as well. I can tell you that if the pathology even shows precancerous cells, or if the gene is +. I will be having a double mx. I just rather not go through the endless cycle of sweating it out every six months as I waiting for my mri results. I personally dont want to keep having biopsy after biopsy because every abnormality will be taken very seriously with my risk factors. Also, my gma had a lumpectomy at 55 when the found a small 8mm mass. It was IDC but had not advanced stage 1. She had two reoccurences that later became bone and lung mets. She chose to use breast conservation measures. All of that said, I do also believe that this is such a very personal decision and the right answer is what YOU feel is right for you! Find a specialist that can help you gather information that will lead you to make an informed decision. I have done that and feel very supported that my decision will be carried out and supported. Also, having lost my mom, dad, and grandmother to cancer, I have felt the pain of losing a loved one to cancer and want to pass along my dearest symapthy to you for the loss of your husband! May God grant you the peace of mind and insight you so need as you go through this journey of discovery. Remember that 80% of these masses come back b9. B9 thoughts for you!
Posts.Title: A question...thinking WAY ahead NurseBeth 2much

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 07:50PM wonderfullymade wrote: KayG, Please let us know how your test goes. I have the same test scheduled as well and have a strong family bc history. I did the gene testing and am waiting for results. I am just 36 and have a something suspicious and thickening of breasts tissue that showed on my mri but not the other imaging! I am very symptomatic with clear sticky nipple drainage and insane itching! I carried my mom and gma through their fights and was not at all thinking i'd be suiting up for battle at this age! I just keep thinking...80% of all lumps are benign! 80% are benign..Will be keeping you and all of these lovely ladies in my prayers! B9 wishes to you!
Posts.Title: MRI Biopsy tomorrow KayG Lisa1962

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2011 07:58AM wonderfullymade wrote: Lisa, Thanks for your words of encouragement! My mom was from Lima, Oh and graduated from OSU. I went to Wittenberg U! Just noticed you are from Athens. I do have my hands full with my tiny men, but according to my mom, who reminded me before her passing that I am wonderfully made, hense the name). These trials and exceptionalities that my children have and she faced with her battle often is comprised of the most amazing and life changing gifts that give us more purpose than we could ever have imagined! I have been reading Psalm 139 alot lately to remind myself, that regardless if this is cancer, I am wonderfully made, if I need to remove my breasts, still, I am wonderfully made. If I should lose my hair to chemo, I am beautiful, becauseÂ I am wonderfully made. If my skin should change because of radiation, I am radiant because, I am wonderfully made. If I am chosen to fight a battle such as my mom and gma, and lose the battle, I will know that I am forever victorious because I am wonderfully made! Not looking to fight cancer, but if I must, I have had some amazing experiencesÂ with strong, gracefull, beautiful woman that I will draw strength from. They are all angels now, but their guidance, love, and presence are more powerful than during their lives! I am greatful to have found this community of strong woman, and am looking forward to developing a cyber relationship with you all!
Posts.Title: MRI Biopsy tomorrow KayG Lisa1962

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 08:34AM wonderfullymade wrote: My results were quite the same this week with atypia, fibrocystic changes, adenosis, adh...my high risk onco said that the adh increases me risk factor from 40%(strong family history) to over 60% now. The office will be formally recaculating my assesment. I am part of a research grant for high risk daughters of women that passed younger than 65 with mets bc. I understand where you are, a b9 result, but not really normal. Well, I feel this result gives me time to deal with other stuff going on in my life because it is slow growing and in some people can be there and never detected or develop into cancer in a life time. I am going to get settled into our new home and move all of my docs and research to another university research center...then proceed. I am still debating on the tomaxifen. Either way, I am very sorry that you have to be thinking of all this. I would focus on your heart. The stuff in your breast wont develop into anything quickly. Gentle hugs for you!!!
Posts.Title: Lots of benign results candybar1 wonderfullymade

Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 09:56PM wonderfullymade wrote: I have dense breasts and am high risk as well. I had an MRI and two MRI guided biopsies in the last two months due to a mass shown on ultrasound and a asymmetrical focal density. Adh and some adenoid tissue was found. The MRI was no biggie and showed abnormalities that no other imaging revealed. I am sorry you have a reason to be posting here, but am very happy to hear that you are having the MRI. Hugs as you anxiously wait for the results.
Posts.Title: spot compression mammography luvvyk46 luvvyk46

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 08:31PM wonderfullymade wrote: bdavis, Your experience is exactly why I am going to proceed with a pbmx once we get settled and moved. I recall my mom and gma doing breast conservation and tomax and both had multiple reoccurances and died of mets bc to liver, lung, and brain. Needless to saym the conservative approach is waisted on me after what I experienced with my family. I do feel that I have some time and will have my six month mri in August and work with the clinic to get the operation scheduled. Each time they said, well, lets do a short interval image in six months, " I responded, why? So we can wait and see if the cancer becomes visible on mammo?" No, thanks, " biopsy it now!" I appreciate your straight forward thinking!

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2011 01:20AM wonderfullymade wrote: I just had the lab drawn about two weeks ago and will have the results this weds. Many larger research facilities have counselors that will help with the collection of info and compile your risk assesment and advocate for you with the insurance company to pay. Mine paid with little fight. My mom, gma, and paternal aunt all had bc, my died died of pancreatic cancer, and my little brother had colon cancer at 25. Needless to say, I had the case to push for testing. I will say that it still is very unlikely to test positive!
Posts.Title: FYI/genetic testing for cancer kpthfaith2 gensi

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2011 08:27PM wonderfullymade wrote: Ladies, I don't want to scare you, but as a daughter and grand daughter of two amazing cancer warriors that passed this year, I must tell you...GET IT CHECKED OUT NOW!!! I was just biopsied, went through six imaging appointments and will be under constant survailence at a high risk clinic forever and believeme, any one of the ladies in this forum if had an option to have a imaging that would have caught their cancer at an earlier stage would take it in a heart beat. I beleive that we ladies know our bodies and know when something is not right. If you are logging on to this forum, then know needs to tell you that you have a consern. You are on here because you have a concern, right? Any concern regarding you breast health should be expressed with your doctor immediately! I may sound forward, but that is just me. I speak the truth and hopefully it will make a small difference in this world! Having said all this, I know what it is like to be in your place, a place of worry and extend a great big hug to you. Now, GO GET THINGS CHECKED OUT!!!

Posts.Title: Where is my cyber mom???? wonderfullymade wonderfullymade

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 09:32AM wonderfullymade wrote: Momma, I just had a few biopsies and I was told to stay away from any blood thining pain meds. Tylenol was fine for pain, but I did not use any! If you are very nervous, ask the doc for anti anxiety med to help you through the preceedure and waiting for pathology. Ativan, xanax,...can be helpful. By the way, all of my results thus far have been b9, hope that calms you a little. Hugs to you!
Posts.Title: Biopsy tomorrow...can pleomorphic be benign? mamatoboyz wonderfullymade

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2011 07:22PM wonderfullymade wrote: dreidteacher, I just read your post and must say that I have seen both my mom and grandmother fight breast cancer, I am now just starting the discovery journey for myself. I have my biopsies scheduled this Friday. I lost both of my parents to cancer within a week of oneanother and had the pleasure of overseeing their hospice and caring for them until they were called home. I must say, I have no experience battling cancer personally, but know how to face struggles head on. I am a mother of two little boys with autism. I think the word journey is very appropriate for this disease. At least that what I witnessed with my mom. Some days she seemed low, in a valley, at times the road seemed bumpy, and other times smooth going. Sometimes it appeared as she was struggling to get up hill and others she was just cruising along. Like all journeys they lead somewhere and each path will be unique for you! You decide what path to take! I see you have found some strong loving and supportive ladies on here and am sure you have many in your life as well. Go ahead and flopped your butt into bed and cry. I certainly would do the same if I were in your shoes. I would also be tempted to slap the next person for you! I am not sure where this journey will lead me. Mom said she learned so much about how to live through her suffering. I can say that I certainly learned a ton! I do know that already my journey has been full of many blessings. I have nowÂ a community of lovely ladies that support me:) Truly. I pray that God sustain you with strength and surround you with loving supportive people while you take this journey! Bless you!
Posts.Title: Had the core biospy yesterday dreidteacher shells43

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2011 06:58PM wonderfullymade wrote: I am very sorry that are dealing with this as young as you are! I am 37 and have two small boys and just had a very similar issue but I have a high risk. I will let you know that I was freaking out but found comfort here and my lump turned out to be a fibroadenoma, b9!! Most of these things are b9. Imaging is not very reliable at our young age so push for all of it! I am thrilled to know that you have an appointment to get going on the diagnosis of this lump! Check in and let us know how you are doing while in this time of discovery. We are all here for you and have been right where you are right now. Please take time to enjoy those hotwheels and spongebob with your little guy, whatever it is will still be there, so why not still play! Easier said than done, I know but try! Hugs!!!
Posts.Title: You ladies rock! Antichrislover Momma

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 07:47AM wonderfullymade wrote: Most breast clinics have free mammo testing. Planned Parent Hood has knowledgable nurse practitioners that can examine you and get tests going for you. You can contact susan g komen from your home and they will have some solutions for you as well. What city are you in? I can help research if you feel comfortable disclosing that info. It is so very hard to manage your own care when all of your loved ones need you. My dad, mom, and gma all died within twelve week of another this summer of cancer and I have two boys with autism, believe me I know where you are! There is a ton of help out there. This will be ok. Oooh, you can contact the local health department and disclose your concern and see if there is a program to help. Many research hospital have financial aid for treatment and screening as well...one step at a time. You need a doc to examine and order imaging first. hugs!!!

It is very reassuring to have a knowlegable bs following your breast health. Many woman fight to get in! Again, congrats on the b9 results!!!
Posts.Title: Biopsy results! Sandy82 wonderfullymade

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 04:42PM wonderfullymade wrote: Julie, Â Your story sounds quite familiar! Meaning, we are in a similar boat. I went to doc because my left breast itched like heck! Because of my family history of breast cancer, colon cancer, and pancreatic cancer, and symptoms, she sent me for a mammo the same day! I am 36 with two young boys with autism. My health care general is neglected for their's is so very intense! I was asked to have an ultrasound to look at a spot. The birads4 as well. I went on to see a genetic counselor and am waiting for my BRCA report. While waiting for that, went to see breast surgeon and he sent me for a breast mri. This took a week to get the insurance company to pay for it. I have very dense breasts and the images are just not clear. I have a mass, calcifications, and thickening tissue on my left breast. I went back to see him on Monday. He scheduled a core needle biopsy and punch biopsy for this Friday, but I had to reschedule because my youngest son has surgery the same day. I will be having my biospies on the 25th. Sending you prayers of healing and grace to keep you calm through this!
Posts.Title: Cluster calcifications found on mammogram OJulie67 gill27

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2011 11:40AM wonderfullymade wrote: Ladies and Julie, Â My little man, just three had his tonsilectomy, ear tubes, and adenoid removal this Friday and is now home and hopefully a quick recovery is underway. I have my biopsies scheduled for this Friday morning and will be seeing the team for pathology reports on Wed morning. I feel good knowing that they already have the followup scheduled! I keep using a positive affirmation, 80% are b9...805 are b9. My screen name is wonderfully made because of two reasons...Psalms 139 says that we are! Also my mother, rest in peace, said to me when I had just realized that I was a mother of not just one son with autism , but two, " Carrie, my real name, they are both wonderfuly made, they are absolutely perfect, the way God intented, and their exceptionalities are a gift to them and you that indeed will give your life more purpose than you ever imagined." She was absolutely right! As she was dying this June at 61, she reminded me, " Don't forget, yu too, are Wonderfully made!" Whatever the outcome maybe, I know that this too is an experience that I will learn from and will share my knowledge gain throught this journey to hopefully bless others. I will be praying for you Julie, that you are blessed with serenity as you anxiously wait for your results. Keep us posted! B9 thoughts to you!
